ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Synchronous and asynchronous components, along with a weekly 15-minute conversation group
Small class size (7 students) in lecture format with discussion during class and during breakout rooms several times per class.
M-W-F virtual seminars, Tu-Th online independent work
Besides in-person seminars on MWF, we had asynchronous work days on TTh.  We watched videos, did worksheets, etc.
NA
Synchronous discussion classes on Monday/ Wednesday/ Friday with asynchronous work to complete in our own time set for Tuesdays and Thursdays
Learning was done through live, virtual synchronous lectures 3 times a week and asynchronous work 2 times a week.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Learned how to speak/comprehend a basic level of German.
I learned the basics of German grammar and developed a good beginning vocabulary.
I got a basic understanding of German.
German Basic Linguistic skills - comprehension, writing, reading, speaking

I gained a thorough grounding in basic German language in a relaxed environment. Lots of speaking and listening practice in class, complemented with reading and writing practice in the homeworks and asynchronous days

I developed a basic level of German comprehension! I went into the course essentially knowing 0 German and went out feeling confident in having a basic conversation in German. Vocabulary, grammar, and syntax were especially emphasized in the course.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Asynchronous components were often lengthy and seemingly-redundant. Besides that, the course was great.

Strengths: synchronous/asynchronous format, Frau Sippel and Herr Pal were really helpful and nice instructors. Weaknesses: Sometimes the assignments we had to do were a little tedious, or didn't seem super helpful for our learning. But mostly was pretty straightforward.

The format of the course (3 synchronous days and 2 asynchronous days) works very well in my opinion as it gives a good balance of new material and time to practice. It is also helpful because it allows for some asynchronous days to be test days, and allows students to take the tests at a time and place that works for them. I think a little bit more time could be spent on pronunciation especially given the online format as it is much more difficult to pick up on pronunciation over a zoom call.
This class was extremely well-taught and organized.  Its biggest strength is the pace - because it is so quick, you learn so much.
The course was excellent and there's little room for improvement.

This is an excellent class taught by excellent professors. The strengths lie in its frequency, meeting three times a week with work set for the two other days, and in its manageable class length (50 mins). The asynchronous days also allowed a lot of flexibility which was very helpful particularly for different time zones. The material covered was varied and interesting, and built upon itself through the semester. I felt a little bit like we learnt a lot more material in the last 3 weeks relative to earlier in the course, especially on the vocabulary side, which perhaps could have been spread through the semester a little bit more. Overall, the structure of the assessments was great and the teaching was phenomenal.

The strengths were definitely the professors and their helpful feedback and corrections on all homework, asynchronous classwork, projects, and tests. However, the commitment to immersing students by only speaking German in class easily led to confusion at times. When new vocabulary was being introduced or German instructions for exercises were hard to understand, my participation and understanding in the course was much less had it been introduced in English.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The synchronous components and conversation groups were extremely engaging.

The combination of synchronous and synchronous lessons was really nice, offered a nice break through the week. Also, the small class size was good since we got more direct attention, breakout rooms were made use of well in this class.

The division of synchronous and asynchronous work worked well as did the use of breakout rooms for practice assignments, however there were sometimes a few too many breakout rooms and they often ate up much of our time.
Breakout rooms were very helpful. But perhaps more opportunities to partner together and chat with students would have been very very useful.

I think the asynchronous/ synchronous split was a huge strength. The extra flexibility it allowed made a huge difference. In addition, the online and virtual activities were generally well thought-out and executed. It was nice to end with an online video project that used all of the skills we had learnt over the semester!

One of the course modifications because of COVID-19 was asynchronous classwork replacing traditional synchronous lectures on Tuesday and Thursday. However, at times, the asynchronous work was quite demanding and longer than the assigned 50 minutes of class. A better gauge as to how to create asynchronous lessons that would last approximately 50 minutes would've been very worthwhile.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! Good introduction, and this is where you would start if you are learning German for the first time (like I was).
Yes, the department does a good job at balancing the pace the course needs to go at with a reasonable workload and I enjoyed my time in class.
Definitely!  If you are thinking about learning German, there is no better way than this course.
Highly recommend

I would highly recommend this course to anyone looking to fulfil a language requirement, or even just looking to pick up the basics of another language. The course is really well structured, the professors are amazing, and the language and culture is really interesting. I learnt a huge amount but didn't feel at any point like the workload was unmanageable, or that I didn't understand what we were learning / couldn't ask questions.
Yes, German is an exciting language to learn, and the grading is fair! Just beware of how fast the course picks up as the semester passes by.
